item.description:
Unleash your inner artist with Fantastiq!

Each round you receive a commission, a title describing the thing you must sculpt. All players make their creations at the same time using the included modeling clay. When everyone is done, it's time for the exhibition! You have to associate the correct title to each sculpture, and you earn points for each correct guess. You also gain points depending on how much your own sculpture has been guessed by the other players!

Similo is a co-operative deduction game with a deck of 90 big cards that show the portrait and name of a famous historical or fictional character, such as Buddha, Mona Lisa, Abraham Lincoln, and Cleopatra.

Your goal is to make the other players guess one character (from the twelve on display in the middle of the table) by playing character cards from your hand. The characters you play must have something in common with that character — whether their profession, appearance, name, and so on, but you can't say why you played who you did! After each turn, the other players remove one or more characters from the table until only the right one remains, and you win...or it is removed, and you lose!

name.value: Lion's Heart, Saracen's Steel: The Battle of Arsuf, September 7, 1191

item.description:
Lion’s Heart, Saracen’s Steel: The Battle of Arsuf, September 7, 1191. This is the latest game in the Battles of the Middle Ages Series, an easy to learn wargame system that tries to recreate most of the principal battles fought from Roman Times to the dawning of Renaissance. These games are designed to be fast and furious, easy to learn and to play, but still true to the historical events portrayed. Lion's Heart, Saracen's Steel portrays the decisive battle of Arsuf. Richard the Lionhearted led the Crusader Army that was confronted by the legendary Ayyubid leader, Saladin. Although the Crusaders emerged victorious in this hard fought battle, the Third Crusade was ultimately a failure. Can you do as well or better?

—user summary

name.value: Trivial Pursuit: AMC – The Walking Dead

item.description:
This edition of Trivial Pursuit features 600 questions from all 7 seasons of of AMC’s The Walking Dead, including characters, locations, events and episodes.

Players score points if they answer a question correctly. A colored die tells you which question to ask.

Challenge the tower where death waits with a fist!

You are a novice in martial arts.
By challenging a number of fighters over the tower of death, your fighting skills will be sharpened. The ultimate goal is to defeat the boss awaiting at the summit, and earn the reputation as the strongest fighter.

However, you are still weak when you first visit the tower.
In order to challenge the boss, you have to gain experience while fighting the rival fighters encountered in the middle of the tower.

Boardgame of Death is a card game with deck building as the major mechanism. Through the use of "Combo" which connects different martial arts skills, damage will be given to rival fighters. The game system allows players to acquire martial arts skills by knocking down enemies.

Let's train your fighter to become the strongest one through repeating scenes of victory and defeat.

—user summary

name.value: Not Men But Devils: The Battle of Camerone

item.description:
Refight the Battle of Camerone, a ten hour fight in the heat and dust near Vera Cruz on April 30th 1863 between the French Foreign Legion and the Mexican army. Regarded as a defining moment in the Foreign Legion's history, after the battle and learning just how few French troops there were, the Mexican commander exclaimed, "These Are Not Men, They Are Devils!"

—description from the publisher
A game in which you can enjoy the tactics of mahjong extremely simply. Exchange your 5 tiles one by one and gain points.

17-Steps is an awareness-raising game. It’s to raise an awareness of the SDGs, there are 17 of them. You can’t talk about achieving the global goals if you don’t first create awareness about it. People need to know what it is. The game originated from the fact that we have 17 SDGs, and the game is supposed to lead you to a paradise. But before you get to that paradise, you have to take 17 steps based on your knowledge of the SDGs.
Atnor (means ‘five’ in Eggon Language) is a game of five. Players are imersed in a tactical environment to have a set of five. Perfect for lovers of logic and strategy.
Gbosi means ‘Symbol of Authority’. It is a game that tells the true story of the fight for a throne between two men. Who gets the throne? Play to find out.

Build your Nigerian home regardless of tribe or religion and be the first to do that if you want to win. The story behind Homia is that Nigeria is a multi-cultural, multi-ethnic and multi-religious country and the player must create a family regardless of the culture or religion. It’s designed to be easy to play. You choose a family and build the family.

Homia is a Memory-style game, where you look at a face down card and try to remember what kind it is. Until you find a homestead tile (also called a "family pad"), you will only memorize where the various tiles are, and put them back face down on the table. Once you finally discover a family pad, you take it into your area. The family pad has various symbols that represent different parts of a household, such as fathers, mothers, sisters, brothers, and pets. The color of the symbol tells you what kind of other cards you will need to complete your family pad. If your family pad has a green symbol, for example, you need to collect one "father" (green background) card to add to your family pad. If there are three yellow symbols on the family pad card, it means he has three daughters, so you'll need to find three of the "daughter" (yellow background) cards to complete your family. If you have a good memory of the cards you looked at before finding your family pad, it will be much easier to find the members of the household required to complete your family pad. Whoever completes their family pad first is the winner!

LUKU-LUKU is an education game with three editions – Noun, Abstract and Map. It’s a fast game and based on the name, it is about how fast your eyes can move. This game tends to make people aware of their surroundings. Lukuluku Map is more of a geographical game while Abstract teaches stars, numbers
and regular shapes in a fun way depending on what the player wants to learn.

LUKU-LUKU is an education game with three editions – Noun, Abstract and Map. It’s a fast game and based on the name, it is about how fast your eyes can move. This game tends to make people aware of their surroundings. Lukuluku Map is more of a geographical game while Abstract teaches stars, numbers
and regular shapes in a fun way depending on what the player wants to learn.

Mgbako (means ‘to calculate’ in Igbo language) is a speed arithetic Boardgame made in Nigeria. Players compete to earn points by beating their opponent in simple arithmetic. It’s not as simple as it sounds. Try winning when the stakes are up and tensions are high.

It’s a folklore of the Igbo culture meaning Proud Woman. Players compete as
soothsayers to save her from her untimely demise.
Oya is a game designed based on the life of a Lagosian (someone who lives in Lagos Nigeria). It explores the Olokpa (police), the JJCs, The Area Boys and hustlers alike. It’s a fast-paced game.

Safe Journi chronicles the journey of a traveller on a Nigerian road. Your fellow players use the obstacles encountered in a Nigerian road to prevent you from reaching your destination. Your task is to manoeuvre the obstacles and get to your destination unharmed.

The Berzuline conference did not go as planned. Tempers are high, fresh wounds come to mind. The treasure lay awaiting exploitation.

It was clear a battle would occur.

UKUBUWA is a misspelt Swahili word for ‘Greatness’, and it takes you through a journey of young people as you earn and lose wealth. , Ukubuwa is a game that takes you through the four stages of life in your perspective.
It starts with the Learning stage (things that affect you in this stage), then takes you to the Idea stage (Talent Development), the Philanthropy level. The interesting thing is that it brings choice and chance to play – chance because you have to roll dice and play, choice because you have to make decisions. It was designed basically for storytelling. While playing, you gain certain things like how to negotiate, how to spend money. It’s the mechanism. Overall, it’s a game of choice and chance.

Legions of Battle are a set of Fantasy wargame rules designed to allow you to fight epic battles between a vast array of creatures and races.

The rules themselves can be tailored to suit any fantasy setting and the game system is designed to allow you to create and field any troops that you like, limited only by your imagination and figures available. A comprehensive points system allows the design of troops as you think they should be represented.

It is now 2017, one hundred years since the United States entered the First World War on the side of the Allies in one of the most unnecessary and wasteful wars ever fought.

The research required almost got in the way of the game system, with diagrams and illustrations. Consequently after system, with diagrams and illustrations. Consequently after many rewrites it was decided to create one book as a game system and another as a simple note book. Both over lap each other. It did seem necessary to describe the tactical techniques in some great detail. Fortunately there is plenty of information on how these weapons were used on the battlefield. This availability of information made it possible to transform information into a realistic game system. However incomplete as it may be, the rules still effectively cover only a small part of the late ground war.

The game system includes supportive diagrams, illustrations, tactical notes and Quick Reference Sheets (Q.R.S.). The Turn Sequence and Turn Phases, once understood, make play easy and fast. The system has two Turn Sequences one of which is optional and the other mandatory. Six basic Turn Phases move the game along to a conclusion. Manufacturers will be glad by the fact that the game is best played using lots of figures and models. Let us be glad that there are sources for figures and models.

Basic units are 12 figures for a platoon with four platoons making a company and three to four companies making a battalion. Figures can be mounted individually or on multiple stands. Morale is based on unit size and applicable modifiers. Movement is with a D-10 die roll for both infantry and tanks. Transport and field artillery movement is determined by the roll of a D-6. There are two Turn Phases in which players can shoot. Hand-to-hand combat is easily performed. Players are always encouraged to adjust the rules to suit their perceptions.

To me, Yanks and Tanks captures the flavor of the late war. I hope your games will be hard fought, yet fun, and the game system competes well with other similar systems.

—description from designer

KOKAGNE 357 is an abstract Domino style tile-laying game for 3 - 6 players.

The goal of the game is to be the first to get rid of all his Kominos.

Players begin the game with 5 Kominos. On his turn, each player places 1 Komino on the table and draws a new one at the end of his turn. Each Komino that is placed on the table (with the exception of the first one) must be orthogonally in contact with at least 3 symbols of previously played Kominos and at least 2 symbols must match. If a player completes an orthogonal or diagonal row with 3, 5, or 7 symbols of the same color/shape, he is allowed to give 1, 2 or 3 Kominos to his opponents.

-description from designer

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
A card game about haemophilia that allows the player to experience what it means to live with this inherited genetic disorder that impairs the body's ability to make blood clots, a process needed to stop bleeding.

This playing game can be played solo or with multiple players. Goal of the game is to score as many points as possible by doing all sorts of activities. More risky activities increase the risk of hemorrhages, which need to be avoided as much as possible.

—description from the designer

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Wow! You have a lot of cats, and they all need to eat. Clash their personalities in fun and exciting ways to feed them kibble and win the game.

Kibble Scuffle is a tactical card game of area control to try to get the best food for your feline friends. With cards like the Robo-Vac and Laser Pointer, you can use toys to strategically distract your opponent's cats. Using the game box as a cat food box to store the food cubes, players take turns placing their cats and resolving their abilities. For example, the Pounce Cat removes a cat at a bowl. The Greedy Cat eats two food cubes. The Mangy Cat forces another cat to move away from their bowl. Once five cats are at any food bowl, the feeding (scoring) phase begins, followed by a new round.

Once a player reaches 20 points, the player with the most value of food cubes eaten at the end of the feeding phase wins.

—description from publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Players in turn put a card on top of the center stack. For a play to be allowed, the played card must display either the same color, or the same shape, than the top card of the stack.

If a player can't comply with this rule with any of his cards, he must draw a card. He may then play it immediately, if able, or pass.

The first player without any card in hand is the winner.

—user summary

You are a hero, a person with great abilities, good temperament, a strong heart, and an even stronger love for spiked eggnog. As you sit in your favorite fur-covered, sheep wool-padded chair, alone in the solitude of greatness, you hear a series of thuds on your roof, followed by what sounds like scratching against the roof tiles. Your neighbor must have lost their gryphon again. You decide to round it back up and, hopefully, you will not need a finger reattachment from the cleric again...
You walk out of your cottage, it is winter but there’s no snow on the ground. Not yet. Climate change has seemed to shift the snow into the early months of the new year (and they say it’s a hoax?). Anyway, the towering buildings of the bustling city can be seen in the distance to your right, it is strange though… you are clearly part of a fantasy world, but the cityscape looks quite modern, like New York, Seattle, or Portland. There’s no time to dwell on the finer details though, you have a gryphon to catch!
When you look up on your roof, you do not see an eagle-lion at all. Rather, to your aghast, you see a very different creature! Above you, holding a bag full of wrapped parcels and decorated from wingtip to tail, is Kringle Klaws! You didn’t even believe in Kringle but here she is, right in front of you. A sack full of gifts and all. What a sight to see! Not only are you shocked that you are beholding Kringle Klaws but you are nearly floored when she starts to speak to you.
“Adventurer,” she says. “Something terrible has happened and I have been forced to seek your aid. I have known of your deeds since that very first piggly-wiggly you saved over in Yazoo and I need your skills. Only you can save our holiday.”
Knowing that you are too stunned to speak, she continues. “Another godly being has come from the land of the Vikings, the fiend calls himself ‘Kris.’ He has stolen my Red Globe of Illumination and I need you to get it back before the sun sets. Without the globe, I cannot deliver the gifts to your fellow humans.”
You have only the whit to ask “Where?”
“I watched him place the globe into a chest strapped to one of his reindeer,” she says. “I was able to follow the furry beast to a fort in the hills not far from here. There, the hooved menace passed by a large illuminated tree and disappeared down some stairs. We need to hurry, I am running out of time.”

—description from the designer

link.value: Adventure Post: A Path of Self-Learning

item.description:
A science thematic explosive card game, it has a high strategy gameplay. Party with your friends in this "ODD-yssey" space time travel!

In DOXA you take the role of a time traveller scientist and your goal is to win the Nobel Prize. However it is not so easy, you must sabotage the strategies of the other players to troll and take advantage of each situation.
You must build the inventions to obtain the Nobel points and when you reach 10 you win the game.
The game has a low-medium strategy level for being a party game, but dont let this fool you, it will test your ability to make combos and decide the best strategy to benefit yourself or to annoy the other players.

A game that combines pictionary, trivial pursuit and snakes&ladders

Players take turns drawing a card; the team gain points if one player can guess the drawing made by his teammate or by answering to the question offered by the card.
Winner is the team that reaches first 48 points.

—user summary

A pinball with a theme of space fight.

The winner is the player who can score the most points with the six white balls. The UFO's at the top of the board, give extra points if you hit them and get them off the ground!

A similar game to Rummy, in that players may pick from the discard pile or face down deck to create a set of five cards, always rounding down to five cards at the end of a turn. A number of "take that" action cards are worked into the deck, swapping player hands, discarding most valuable sets, etc.
—user summary

Maki Staki is a stylish sushi themed card game for three to six players. Simply collect sets of sushi cards to make your Maki but be ready to roll with the action cards. Will you fall foul of the Fatal Fugu or Wasabi Burn or will you pass the buck with the help of the Conveyor Belt?
—description from the publisher

Timeline: ÄŒesko is a card game played using 110 cards. Each card depicts an event on both sides, with the year in which that it occurred on only one side. Players take turns placing a card from their hand in a row on the table. After placing the card, the player reveals the date on it. If the card was placed correctly with the date in chronological order with all other cards on the table, the card stays in place; otherwise the card is removed from play and the player takes another card from the deck.

The first player to get rid of all his cards by placing them correctly wins. If multiple players go out in the same round, then everyone else is eliminated from play and each of those players are dealt one more card for another round of play. If only one player has no cards after a bonus round, he wins; otherwise play continues until a single player goes out.

Timeline: ÄŒesko adds cards with events from Czech Republic and can be combined with any other title in the Timeline series.

A Gamebook where you can face firsthand the horrors told by H. P. Lovecraft among the most famous classic stories of The Cthulhu Mythos: Dagon, The Festival and The Hound (you'll also find a Dreamlands' section, with some striking extracts from The Dream-Quest of Unknown Kadath).

The stories were adapted with the utmost fidelity to the original text, in order to allow you an interactive immersion in the style of the Master of the Supernatural, by using a narration with paths, where, armed with a die and a pencil, you will travel through the streets of Kingsport facing monstrous creatures, exploring nightmarish territories and crossing the border that divides dream from reality. Will you be able to prevent the Yule ritual from taking place, saving humanity from a gruesome fate, or will you just go crazy?

—description from the publisher

Politics can be dirty and politics can be frustrating but now politics can be fun with this fast-paced exciting card game. Players work to win the nomination of their party in the first phase of play then join together in teams to compete in the national election. Votes are gained by using political influence in this trick-taking game. Do you have what it takes to run for office and lead your country to greatness or, at least, have a lot of fun trying?

Run For Office is played in two phases of seven rounds each. The first phase is the Primary where each player works to win the nomination of their own party. The second phase is the Election where players work together in two competing teams to elect a president (winner).

In the Primary, each player gets a party, negotiates a platform by trading cards, and then gains Influence Cards. The Influence Cards are used to win Vote Cards by taking tricks. The Top two players who collect the most votes in their party are the winners of the Primary. The remaining players form teams with the two winners and a final Election takes place. Again, players gain Influence Cards to take Vote Cards through tricks but must do so in teams. The party members with the most votes at the end of the Election are the winners.

-description from designer

Play as either The Warden or as one of five playable Gang Leaders.

Gang Leaders must plot intricate escape plans and procure escape equipment from across the prison to help navigate one of their many loyal Inmates to Freedom before Turn 29, whilst simultaneously competing with backstabbing rival Gang Leaders, and a perverse Warden.

The game plays between 2-6 players. And is played on a 6pc 89cm x 56cm board.

An average Story Mode game lasts between 100-150 Mins.

The final board will contains an island prison contained within two separate Security Fences, the Inner Prison Walls, and exterior buildings (both marked out with grey outlined hexes).
The board is split into 6 segments/’Sectors’ upon which the prison Searchlight and Watchtowers exercise control over using specific ‘Warden Cards’.
There are eight potential Freedom Hexes (marked out with the stars and stripes) that an Inmate of a Gang must reach first (before another Gang Leader can) to Win.

The boardgame also includes three playable modes: Story Mode, Arcade Mode, and Team Mode.

—description from the publisher

Katag: Le jeu de carte is a two players card games.
Each play have is own deck and try to defeat the four other players heroes by playing object cards and action cards.
On his turn, each player is playing one of his four heroes.
Then, according to each hero's action points and object points, a player can give objects and actions from his hand to his engaged Hero.
By comparing attack and defense, one of the hero defeats the other.
First player to defeat the four opposing heroes is the winner.

—user summary

Hilarious Headline Card Game! This game is a little different. You're dealt a hand of Headline Cards with words on them, each with a point value. When it's your turn, construct the headline that earns the highest points... and often the biggest laughs! The winner is the first player to get 500 points.

Grown-up fans of Man Bites Dog will love this adult twist!

The aim of the game is to be elected President by the majority. This means getting the necessary votes to win more than half of the seats in the National Congress.

In order to get the votes, everything is allowed. Deals with other political parties, buying judges, cheating... but you also need to take into account the other political parties and luck!

You can also choose your lifestyle and what proposals you are going to invest the money from your campaign into. Also you need to decide what you are going to do during your time as President to ensure you win the elections for the following year.

Each turn, players will roll the dice and move their token on the track - either clockwise or counter-clockwise. They then draw a card from a pile corresponding to the colour of the space they landed on. Each colour has its own actions associated with it: Green for political expertise, black for family life, purple for business, gold for bribe and deals.

During the game, several elections are held. During each elections, players invest money - which buys them votes. These translated in positions in congress, which will give back money. There are also special positions, which will give you different advantages. A player wins the game if he manages to get a majority during the elections (50%+1).

Players can negotiate alliances, which allows them to share the benefits of special positions - though it is not possible to win together.

Can YOU Draw A Rose With YOUR Nose?

Think you've got a nose for drawing? In this hilarious party game, players use their sniffers to sketch objects and then hope their teammates can correctly guess what they're drawing before time runs out! Simply pick a card and then, using the special Pencil Nose glasses, try to draw the object onto the screen - USING ONLY YOUR NOSE!

—description from the publisher

On the berries, get set, go! Who is the fastest hedgehog at the annual hedgehog race? In this original color cube running game, the colorful berries set the pace ... Since it may happen that one or the other berry is lost or stolen by another hedgehog. Squirrel and mouse are waiting for the festive Beerenschmaus at the finish. An exciting race for the berries! For children from 4 years.
Improvement of the POLIS is a gamer's game in which you develop the city-states of ancient Greece by utilizing the characteristics of each city-state.

In the Bike Route players build bike routes around the city winning community rewards. The first player to 7 points wins. The game is filled with art and locations that you will recognize and fill you with joy as you build bike routes to connect different places together.

The game includes exquisite paintings of local landmarks and locations both past, present and future. This is not the Sacramento of today but a Sacramento of the imagination, with ideas that excite the spirit, from the historical past to the hopeful future. Bike Route includes everything from the majestic Alhambra movie palace to the soon to be completed Powerhouse Science Center on the river. All the wonderful things that you think about when you imagine Sacramento are included. Come play in the Sacramento that never was but will always exist in our hearts.

Each turn you can take one of four actions.
1. Draw a new route card
2. Add 1 or 2 pawns to the board
3. Draw 2 pawns from the bag
4. Return pawns to the bag and draw the same number.
In addition each turn you can score 1 completed route card.

Bike Route has a long history and has been in development for over 10 years. Originally called Connections the game was never published and looked like it would end up on the pile of great ideas that never were. My daughter AR kept it alive by insisting that we play. "Papa lets play Connections" she would say and we would play. Despite the weak art the game was good and we kept enjoying the drama of the game. Eventually we decided that it should be brought back with new artwork and Bike Route was born. Connections was at heart a game about building connections between places and it seemed a perfect fit for a game about building bike routes. The idea took off and it has kept going ever since.

Bike route is for people who love bikes, love games and love Sacramento.

—description from the designer

This floor plan-themed party game is in the style of the classic "telephone game."

18 floor plan cards are spread across a table. Using the game's special app, players can explore the rooms of a house.

One player looks around inside the rooms, and uses words and gestures to describe what they look like.
The other players try to find the corresponding floor plan card from among the cards on the table.

—description from the publisher

Overlap is a card game using small, square cards, each with nine squares that are each colored red, yellow, or blue. The goal of the game is to score points by placing cards such that squares of the same color align. As the name suggests, the cards can overlap one another, adding another level of strategy and requiring spatial-reasoning and critical thinking skills.

How to play:

Set up: Shuffle the deck of cards, then deal each player five cards. Each player places this stack of cards face down in front of them. Place one card from the deck face up in the center of the playing surface.

Gameplay: Choose a starting player. That player draws the top card from his/her stack and plays it on the playing surface following card placement rules, and then calculates and records his/her score for the turn. Play then continues clockwise. When all players have placed all their cards, the round ends and the cards are shuffled back into the deck. The number of rounds corresponds with the number of players, with each player having an opportunity to go first.

Card placement: Cards may be placed adjacent to other cards in play, but they must be played so that at least one square aligns with a square on an adjacent card. Additionally, they may be played so that the cards partially overlap, as long as the squares align. When cards are played, at least one square must lie over an empty space (you cannot occlude 9 squares with any given card.)

Scoring: When you place a card, any instance in which a square of a certain color lies next to a square of that same color on another card is worth one point. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins!

-description from designer

name.value: Adventure Post: A Path of Self-Learning

item.description:
Adventure Post is a series of solo-mini-adventures delivered to your door on a postcard each week. Every week is a small portion of an overall larger campaign which will take many, many weeks to come to conclusion. The postcard will include a QR code or website address that will direct you to the weekly adventure document. The document will explain the setup, instructions, and key areas on the adventure map.

A Path of Self-Learning uses simplistic character creation and dice rolls for combat and interacting with the world. There are a series of questions, all of which alter the final conflict of the game in various ways. On the 12th week, the adventure will be completed and to survive is to win.

The Story:
As punishment for a crime committed against humanity, the Lord of the land has sentenced you to a Trial of Character. You must be judged against both physical and mental challenges in which you will discover who you truly are. You will learn about the three principles, Truth, Love, and Courage. You will face moral dilemmas in each of the eight virtues where your answers must be considered carefully. Finally, you will face a mighty foe in one-on-one combat. A foe whose power is a reflection of the choices you have made. Can you prove yourself worthy to earn your mantle back, Avatar?

A Path of Self-Learning is only the first adventure in a larger overall campaign. There are more aventures of different themes and new rules on the horizon.

—description from the publisher

name.value: Storm over Yasuda Auditorium, University of Tokyo

item.description:
Storm over Yasuda Auditorium, University of Tokyo is a two-player game of "Yasuda Auditorium Incident", a conflict between Tokyo Metropolitan Police's riot squad and All Campus Joint Struggle League, January 18-19, 1969 during University of Tokyo Protests.

FYI
https://features.japantimes.co.jp/student-riots/

The game system is based on Avalon Hill's Storm over Arnhem.
Riot Police player aims to remove university students from Yasuda Auditorium (and the surrounding buildings). University Students player aims to block it.

June, 1944: Through the D-Day landings, the Allies have seized a foothold on the beaches of Normandy. Now you must lead your troops forward as you push deeper into France and drive the German forces back. You will face intense resistance, machine gun fire, and mortar bombardment, but a great commander can turn the situation to their advantage!

Undaunted: Normandy is a deck-building game that places you and your opponent in command of American or German forces, fighting through a series of missions critical to the outcome of World War II. Use your cards to seize the initiative, bolster your forces, or control your troops on the battlefield. Strong leadership can turn the tide of battle in your favor, but reckless decisions could prove catastrophic as every casualty you take removes a card from your deck. Take charge amidst the chaos of battle, hold fast in the face of opposition, and remain undaunted.

—description from the publisher

It's a party game for 2-4 girls.
The goal of the game is to collect the most kisses.

Every girl tries to collect the most kisses on her friend photo. But as in real life, there are lots of problems, obstacles and impediments....

A really nice and fun alphabet game. Let children learn the alphabet while they play a suerfun game.

Littlestorm Activity is a creative and learning-rich children's game which is filled with entertaining action.

The game can either be played as a team game or individually.
Singolo is a chess variant where the player moves like the horse. All 64 fields of the board needs to be touched exactely once.

The more you win, the more you lose!

The object of the game is to demonstrate the pitfalls of gambling. This is an educational game for young people (ages 6-19). It teaches them that although gambling sometimes brings in big money for them, most of the time it ends up with heavy loses, resulting in accumulated debts and addictive behavior.
—description from the rulebook

Gain Less is a roll-and-move game, with a number of "betting" spaces for players to spend money at. There is always a chance of winning more money back than you have spent, but the game is designed so that you lose money more often than win, similar to the odds found at casinos and other gambling houses. Gain Less is an educational game, used to demonstrate to young teenagers and adults that when you gamble, ultimately you lose more money than you win.
—user summary
The players try to move their pieces to the center of the game board. But be careful: The other players should not find out which piece is yours! Therefore, bluffing is an essential part of the game.

The easiest way to the Euro!
A family board game that can be played from 2-6 persons. Although Euro-Mille is directly linked to the Euro conversion, it can still be played as a nostalgic game to remember the good old times with different currencies in all countries across Europe.

The game includes a CD with 33 recorded sounds, such as a church bell, a glass breaking, a car crash, a duck, etc.

Every player gets 5 cards and as soon as the sound from one of his card is played, he must put it down as fast as possible.

Detective Jigsaw Puzzling Game: Sweet Death

First, the players read some information about a criminal case. With this information, they start creating a jigsaw puzzle which gives them addtional hints to eventually solve the overall criminal case.

Fatal Truffles! 
Armande de Coca is dead - next to him the best sweets from all over the world...

Detective Jigsaw Puzzling Game: Purring whitnesses

First, the players read some information about a criminal case. With this information, they start creating a jigsaw puzzle which gives them addtional hints to eventually solve the overall criminal case.

The only whitnesses for the murder of Millicent Manners are her cats.

Detective Jigsaw Puzzling Game: Murder in the atelier

First, the players read some information about a criminal case. With this information, they start creating a jigsaw puzzle which gives them addtional hints to eventually solve the overall criminal case.

Albert Thomas, a well-known artist and art faker is dead. Who killed him?

Detective Jigsaw Puzzling Game: Fatal Diet

First, the players read some information about a criminal case. With this information, they start creating a jigsaw puzzle which gives them addtional hints to eventually solve the overall criminal case.

Claudia Culpepper is killed in an exclusive spa while she wanted to go for a midnight meal...

The Boy Who Cried Wolf is a bluffing game for 3-5 players. Each player takes a turn as the "boy" and will look at the top card of the deck and either cry wolf or pass. The deck is filled with lots of sheep and just a few scary wolves. If a boy cries wolf, each player decides whether he is telling the truth or lying. After they all give a thumbs up or thumbs down, the card is revealed. If it was a lie, the boy gets points for each player that fell for it. If it was the truth, players that thought it was a lie will lose points. Play until a player reaches 10 points, or 5 wolves attack.

Detective Jigsaw Puzzling Game: Fatal spending spree

First, the players read some information about a criminal case. With this information, they start creating a jigsaw puzzle which gives them addtional hints to eventually solve the overall criminal case.

A mysterious crime in a shopping mall where 2 men wear the same shirts and one of them is dead now...

Detective Jigsaw Puzzling Game: Rates of Nice

First, the players read some information about a criminal case. With this information, they start creating a jigsaw puzzle which gives them addtional hints to eventually solve the overall criminal case.

This game deals with one of the biggest bank robberies ever.

name.value: Warren Wars: Living on Burrowed Time

item.description:
Warren Wars is a game about racing to be the first to build your army while your opponents are trying to steal your Carrots and bunnies.

Each player takes turns first drawing a card and then playing a card. Everyone is aiming to be the winner by being the first to fill their Warren with five Recruits or by being the last player standing after wiping out everyone else.

There will be card stealing, taking over other players’ turns, all while trying to maintain their own Warrens.

—description from the publisher

Psychobunnies – What’s that then?

It’s an incredibly addictive tabletop card game that challenges your memory & strategy skills whilst still having an element of luck that can come around to bite you on the backside when you least expect it. Oh, and it’s got psychotic bunnies. Don’t forget the bunnies.

To win the game, you need to ensure you have the lowest score possible each round. The last bunny standing is the winner. That might sound easy, but with only 10 seconds to view half or your drawn cards and the other half of your hand a complete mystery, it soon becomes more of a challenge!

Play can become incredibly strategic (e.g. do you 'play safe' and try to attain low scoring cards, or do you collect high scoring cards that others are more likely to discard, running the risk of being stuck with them when play ends?).

Then there's the element of luck. You have no idea what half of your deck contains. Sometimes at the end of a round, they're as much as a surprise to you as to the rest of the players. This can be a good or a bad thing! Add to that several 'Trick or Treat' cards designed to test your skills (and your sanity), and Psychobunnies is an absolute riot to play.

No bunnies were harmed in the making of this game.

—description from the designer
This is an exciting memory game with Mickey and his friends for 2-6 young players.

Maia Strongheart stands alone against the world. A cabal of conspirators has framed her for the death of her own mother, the Sun Queen, and they intend to usurp the throne from her family. To prove her own innocence and reclaim her birthright, Maia must step into the proving grounds to complete a trial that will stretch her combat skills to the limit. Will the Wizened's chosen daughter vanquish her foes in the arena? Or will she be overwhelmed by the conspirators and their evil aspirations?

Proving Grounds is a real-time solitaire dice game that merges narrative and gameplay in a brand-new way. In this box, you will find a novella, "Only the Strongest Has the Heart of a Wizened Queen", written by Monica Valentinelli. This sweeping story sets the stage for the events of the game. Read the story of Maia Strongheart as she fights to ascend to the Sun Throne, then recreate her extraordinary battle!

Proving Grounds has a training game and six different gameplay modules. Once you've learned the basics, add a single module or mix and match to your tastes. If you're feeling truly adventurous, put them all together for a true test of your gladiatorial combat skills!

—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable
